metadata.title: The Effects of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 on the Southern Seamless Hosiery and Lumber Industries

dependent_variables.displaced: The entire net job loss for the industry over the two-year period was due to cutbacks in low-wage firms.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Employment in the southern lumber industry would likely have been more adversely affected but for two factors: changes in the resource base and firms avoiding the minimum wage.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: In 1940, approximately one-third of workers in the seamless hosiery industry earned no more than 2.5 cents over the 32.5 cent minimum rate.

text_fragments: 'The [FLSA] as a whole presents itself to us as a reincarnation of the NRA in a more virulent form.'
'A flat minimum price means paying a sorry slow-moving, devil-may-care, good-for-nothing specimen as much as a good man that is worth two to five times as much anywhere-anytime.'
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how the FLSA led to increased mechanization in the hosiery industry and evasion of wage laws in the lumber industry.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The period was marked by war-related government purchases and changes in the resource base.
historical_context.institutional_context: The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 imposed a binding minimum wage on certain industries.

outcomes.main_findings: The FLSA led to increased mechanization in the hosiery industry and evasion of wage laws in the lumber industry.
outcomes.conclusions: The minimum wage had a significant impact on employment policies and production processes in low-wage firms.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The FLSA may have made foreign imports more competitive, particularly of low-cost products produced by unskilled labor.
